The Act titled "Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998" amends Section 3001 of title 39, United States Code to regulate mailings containing solicitations or offers related to sales promotions or games of skill with the chance to win something of value. The Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 amends Section 3001 of title 39, United States Code to regulate mailings containing solicitations or offers related to sales promotions or games of skill with the chance to win something of value. Regulations issued by the Postmaster General dictate that non-compliant mail shall not be delivered and must be disposed of as directed by the Postal Service. These regulations require clear disclosure statements in game promotion mailings, outlining that recipients are not obligated to purchase to win, accurately stating the chances of winning, and advising that purchases do not increase chances of winning. Games of chance mailings must also be clearly labeled. The Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 amends Section 3001 of title 39, United States Code to regulate mailings containing solicitations or offers related to sales promotions or games of skill with the chance to win something of value. The act requires clear labeling of games of chance mailings and prohibits misleading statements guaranteeing winners. It also prohibits solicitations from representing recipients as members of a selected group with enhanced chances of winning. The Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 amends Section 3001 of title 39, United States Code to regulate mailings containing solicitations or offers related to sales promotions or games of skill with the chance to win something of value. It requires clear labeling of games of chance mailings, prohibits misleading statements guaranteeing winners, and prohibits representations of recipients as members of a selected group with enhanced chances of winning. Additionally, Chapter 30 of title 39 is amended to authorize the Postmaster General to use administrative subpoenas in investigations, allowing the production of relevant records. The Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 amends Section 3001 of title 39, United States Code to regulate mailings containing solicitations or offers related to sales promotions or games of skill with the chance to win something of value. It authorizes the use of administrative subpoenas in investigations, allowing service in a foreign country and jurisdiction by the United States District Court for the District of Columbia. The Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 allows service of subpoenas on partnerships, corporations, associations, or entities by delivering a copy to authorized agents, the principal office, or by mail. Subpoenas can also be served on individuals by delivering a copy or mailing it. The Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 allows subpoenas to be served on individuals or entities by delivering a copy in person or by registered mail. Failure to comply may result in enforcement by the Postmaster General through the Attorney General in the district court. The Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 allows subpoenas to be served on individuals or entities for enforcement through the district court. The court has jurisdiction to enter orders to carry out the provisions of the Act, with disobedience punishable as contempt. Any documentary material provided under a subpoena is exempt from disclosure. The Postal Service must issue regulations within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Postal Service must issue regulations for implementing the Deceptive Games of Chance Mailings Elimination Act of 1998 within 180 days of enactment. The Postal Service can assess civil penalties of $10,000 per violation for mailing nonmailable matter under section 3012 of title 39, United States Code. Regulations will be prescribed to enforce this provision.
